snippet.textDisplay:
They used to use these to align computer data tapes too.

When I was at school back in the late 1970s, the maths teacher managed to obtain for the school a mid 60's Digital PDP 4 computer, complete with 64K of 18-bit magnetic core memory, a teletype, and two types of magnetic tape drive - DEC tape and something bigger. The whole thing came in vast pale blue cabinets, was fully transistorised apart from the valves in the power supply (no ICs back then!), and required a 30 amp 3 phase power source..

It was completely obsolete when he bought it - for £10 - from the Harwell nuclear research place, including stacks of spares, manuals, etc.. But we managed to get it going, and I used it to produce my A level computer science project - a text editor written in PDP-4 machine code - goodness knows how they marked it!

In amongst the spares and manuals was one of these magnetic tape viewers - almost identical to this one, though I seem to remember it came nestled in an oaken box with a green baize lining. Good find!
snippet.textOriginal:
They used to use these to align computer data tapes too.

When I was at school back in the late 1970s, the maths teacher managed to obtain for the school a mid 60's Digital PDP 4 computer, complete with 64K of 18-bit magnetic core memory, a teletype, and two types of magnetic tape drive - DEC tape and something bigger.  The whole thing came in vast pale blue cabinets, was fully transistorised apart from the valves in the power supply (no ICs back then!), and required a 30 amp 3 phase power source..

It was completely obsolete when he bought it - for £10 - from the Harwell nuclear research place, including stacks of spares, manuals, etc..  But we managed to get it going, and I used it to produce my A level computer science project - a text editor written in PDP-4 machine code - goodness knows how they marked it!

In amongst the spares and manuals was one of these magnetic tape viewers - almost identical to this one, though I seem to remember it came nestled in an oaken box with a green baize lining.  Good find!

snippet.textDisplay: You could use that device to see the track info in your credit card too. You can actually see it well enough to count and decipher the data contained there without any electronic equipment. Talk about analog!
snippet.textOriginal: You could use that device to see the track info in your credit card too. You can actually see it well enough to count and decipher the data contained there without any electronic equipment. Talk about analog!

snippet.textDisplay: In the mid 80's I was manufacturing plastic sheet magnets, the kind with advertising stuck on a refrigerator.  We had sheets of plastic like this to view the magnetic field we gave away.  Probably not this sensitive, but still one of the worlds small wonders. I still remember the welding cables jumping when we zapped the magnetizer bar with 20,000A.
snippet.textOriginal: In the mid 80's I was manufacturing plastic sheet magnets, the kind with advertising stuck on a refrigerator.  We had sheets of plastic like this to view the magnetic field we gave away.  Probably not this sensitive, but still one of the worlds small wonders. I still remember the welding cables jumping when we zapped the magnetizer bar with 20,000A.

snippet.textDisplay: Just to add that a 'relative' of this product was used (back in the day!) to aid the editing of those original Ampex 2" QUAD video tapes. A "ferro-fluid" liquid (similar to that contained in the 3M vial) was painted onto the recorded tape and it displayed the sync pulses of the recorded material, allowing the cut to be made outside the 'picture' field, and hence maintaining the flow of the programme (i.e the picture didn't roll, or shouldn't have!!).
snippet.textOriginal: Just to add that a 'relative' of this product was used (back in the day!) to aid the editing of those original Ampex 2" QUAD video tapes. A "ferro-fluid" liquid (similar to that contained in the 3M vial) was painted onto the recorded tape and it displayed the sync pulses of the recorded material, allowing the cut to be made outside the 'picture' field, and hence maintaining the flow of the programme (i.e the picture didn't roll, or shouldn't have!!).

snippet.textDisplay: Hi Techmoan I use a tool like this on a weekly basis in the motor vehicle industry, Many ABS systems have a magnetic ring built into the wheel bearing of a vehicle, often a replacement bearing comes with a "FREE" viewing tool to identify the abs reader side of the bearing so to press it in correctly. the tool can be used to view for cracks or errors on a faulty abs system but works in the same way as yours, we are just looking for a uniform stripe pattern. I have linked a quickly found youtube video as an example as it was the first one I found : https://youtu.be/e32t-d32SEg
snippet.textOriginal: Hi Techmoan I use a tool like this on a weekly basis in the motor vehicle industry, Many ABS systems have a magnetic ring built into the wheel bearing of a vehicle, often a replacement bearing comes with a "FREE" viewing tool to identify the abs reader side of the bearing so to press it in correctly. the tool can be used to view for cracks or errors on a faulty abs system but works in the same way as yours, we are just looking for a uniform stripe pattern. I have linked a quickly found youtube video as an example as it was the first one I found : https://youtu.be/e32t-d32SEg

snippet.textDisplay: I’ve been looking out for one of these for years as well. The old 3M ones are really nice. I’ve heard the fluid inside this is pretty toxic/harmful, so I’d definitely handle it with caution! These are particularly useful in a studio situation when you’ve got a bunch of tapes that are poorly labeled and you need an easy/fast way to see if they’re full-track mono or 2 track stereo, or for whatever odd reason mono recorded on a 2 track machine and you’re wondering why it sounds terrible on a mono head (which has absolutely happened before)
snippet.textOriginal: I’ve been looking out for one of these for years as well. The old 3M ones are really nice. I’ve heard the fluid inside this is pretty toxic/harmful, so I’d definitely handle it with caution! These are particularly useful in a studio situation when you’ve got a bunch of tapes that are poorly labeled and you need an easy/fast way to see if they’re full-track mono or 2 track stereo, or for whatever odd reason mono recorded on a 2 track machine and you’re wondering why it sounds terrible on a mono head (which has absolutely happened before)

snippet.textDisplay: What an interesting product. I worked for IBM in the 80's as a service engineer and we had 'IBM Tape Developer'. This was a bottle of alcohol with very fine iron particles suspended in it. You gave the bottle a good shake and brushed the solution onto the magnetic tape. The alcohol evaporated leaving the filings showing up the tracks on the tape. Once you had checked track alignment etc you just wiped the particles off with a cloth. I wonder why they did not use this sort of gadget? Maybe because it was a digital signal on the tape and it would not show up.
snippet.textOriginal: What an interesting product. I worked for IBM in the 80's as a service engineer and we had 'IBM Tape Developer'. This was a bottle of alcohol with very fine iron particles suspended in it. You gave the bottle a good shake and brushed the solution onto the magnetic tape. The alcohol evaporated leaving the filings showing up the tracks on the tape. Once you had checked track alignment etc you just wiped the particles off with a cloth. I wonder why they did not use this sort of gadget? Maybe because it was a digital signal on the tape and it would not show up.

snippet.textDisplay:
Can do the same with a Laser pointer Shining on a tape

Laser pointer
https://www.amazon.co.uk/s?k=laser+pointer

Tenlacum Optical Concave Convex Lens Prism Set Physical Optical Kit
https://www.amazon.co.uk/Tenlacum-Physical-Laboratory-Equipment-Generator/dp/B07ZCV7CY9/

you know laser light sparkles with defects right ... it happens to do it with magnetic fields
It also tad more sensitive to the weaker magnetic fields [magneto-optical]

It a shame they never used lasers for Tape, VHS, batamax, 8 track
Shame nones hacked a optical mouse/ barcode scanner yet [Flood light sub Laser LED] and see if they can make a Virtual magnetic optical pickup head in software

It reminds me of SDR Radio + Sound Forge Studio
https://imgur.com/a/IXJd6tx
snippet.textOriginal:

you know laser light sparkles with defects right ... it happens to do it with magnetic fields

snippet.textDisplay: We use to use this device to edit video Quad videotape at the very end of the 2" Quadrplux video era shortly thereafter electronic editing came into fashion. The alternative method used carbon tetrachloride solution to reveal the video tracks under a magnifying lens and allowing the tape to be mechanically spliced at the vertical interval thereby preventing a video "glitch." 3M was never very good at marketing as this device would have been a lot safer and easier but never was used widely as "carbon tet" was cheaper though obviously dangerous.
snippet.textOriginal: We use to use this device to edit video Quad videotape at the very end of the 2" Quadrplux video era shortly thereafter electronic editing came into fashion. The alternative method used carbon tetrachloride solution to reveal the video tracks under a magnifying lens and allowing the tape to be mechanically spliced at the vertical interval thereby preventing a video "glitch." 3M was never very good at marketing as this device would have been a lot safer and easier but never was used widely as "carbon tet" was cheaper though obviously dangerous.

snippet.textDisplay: Re not working on floppy disks: curses! I do work decoding old floppy disk formats (<plug> http://cowlark.com/fluxengine </plug>) and being able to see the data would be really useful. Or maybe just interesting. Incidentally, regarding the fluid, I ran into someone who used it non-destructively on floppy disks by placing a sheet of cellophane over the disk and applying the fluid to the cellophane. It's thin enough not to disturb the signals but keeps the fluid off the disk. Sadly the fluid is stupidly expensive and you only get to use it once, so I've never bothered.
snippet.textOriginal: Re not working on floppy disks: curses! I do work decoding old floppy disk formats (<plug> http://cowlark.com/fluxengine </plug>) and being able to see the data would be really useful. Or maybe just interesting. Incidentally, regarding the fluid, I ran into someone who used it non-destructively on floppy disks by placing a sheet of cellophane over the disk and applying the fluid to the cellophane. It's thin enough not to disturb the signals but keeps the fluid off the disk. Sadly the fluid is stupidly expensive and you only get to use it once, so I've never bothered.

snippet.textDisplay: Try checking a prerecorded 4-track tape. Machines never seem to be adjusted to place the tracks equally spaced across the tape. The space between the tracks should ideally be equal. But alignment instructions tell you to have the top of the heads pole piece just slightly above the edge of the tape. This results in what we see here, and causes increased playback interference from the adjacent track. Which you hear faintly playing, backwards. So it would be interesting on a prerecorded tape. One of the other products used to view tracks on tape is a liquid called Magna-See made by Soundcraft a division of CBS Records. I have a can of this, which I've had since sometime in the 80's. I used it to check track placement on 9-track computer tape. The tape is dipped into the liquid and the solvent evaporates  leaving behind a very find dust of iron particles showing the tracks. And it doesn't harm the tape or data on the tape. You just wipe it off and the tape is just fine. This also will show the tracks on a VHS tape, Beta too. And yes, I repair and collect reel to reel machines. And perfection is always the goal. And hang onto that full track width tape. Can be used to adjust head azimuth if lacking a very expensive calibration tape.
snippet.textOriginal: Try checking a prerecorded 4-track tape. Machines never seem to be adjusted to place the tracks equally spaced across the tape. The space between the tracks should ideally be equal. But alignment instructions tell you to have the top of the heads pole piece just slightly above the edge of the tape. This results in what we see here, and causes increased playback interference from the adjacent track. Which you hear faintly playing, backwards. So it would be interesting on a prerecorded tape. One of the other products used to view tracks on tape is a liquid called Magna-See made by Soundcraft a division of CBS Records. I have a can of this, which I've had since sometime in the 80's. I used it to check track placement on 9-track computer tape. The tape is dipped into the liquid and the solvent evaporates  leaving behind a very find dust of iron particles showing the tracks. And it doesn't harm the tape or data on the tape. You just wipe it off and the tape is just fine. This also will show the tracks on a VHS tape, Beta too. And yes, I repair and collect reel to reel machines. And perfection is always the goal. And hang onto that full track width tape. Can be used to adjust head azimuth if lacking a very expensive calibration tape.

snippet.textDisplay: This is fantastic; I get analog tapes to transfer all the time, and it's almost always a guessing game as to which format has been used.  Most consumers "back in the day" just didn't know enough to at least mark the box.  Now I can "Look" at the tape itself and know ahead of time.  Thanks for posting!
snippet.textOriginal: This is fantastic; I get analog tapes to transfer all the time, and it's almost always a guessing game as to which format has been used.  Most consumers "back in the day" just didn't know enough to at least mark the box.  Now I can "Look" at the tape itself and know ahead of time.  Thanks for posting!

snippet.textDisplay: As a Computer Field Service Engineer we used to use similar devices to check and adjust head alignment on vacuum column tape decks.  Important job to get right as if you just slapped a new head into a deck it probably wouldnt be able to read older tapes - pretty important for getting data from backup tapes!
snippet.textOriginal: As a Computer Field Service Engineer we used to use similar devices to check and adjust head alignment on vacuum column tape decks.  Important job to get right as if you just slapped a new head into a deck it probably wouldnt be able to read older tapes - pretty important for getting data from backup tapes!
